author: Giselle Sanchez
title: Music and laughter in Abu Dhabi
text:
by Giselle Sanchez
October 20, 2015 I had fun over the weekend with Aiza Seguerra, Darren Espanto, Derek Ramsay and Joey Generoso at the very first Abu Dhabi Music Festival.
More than 5,000 people, including a huge number of Filipinos, filled up the posh Abu Dhabi Golf Club to participate in the six-hour extravaganza which looked and felt like Woodstock – with chairs!
I was particularly impressed with 14-year-old Darren Espanto. His vocal range was such that he could actually reach the high notes on his cover of Ariana Grande’s “Bang Bang” and Sia’s “Chandelier.” No wonder he has fans all over the world.
LIZA DIÑO takes a groufie with the concert performers (from left): Giselle Sanchez, Joey G., Aiza Seguerra, Darren Espanto and producer Christine Gonzales
The Darrenatics UAE, ranging from teens to grandparents, occupied around 10 rows in front of the stage. Some of them traveled three hours from Dubai to see their idol.
Backstage, I asked former Side A vocalist Joey G. if his former band is okay with him going solo and he shared, “Side A has been together for 25 years. It was a good journey. They are still my friends we are all happy for each other’s success. They respect my decision and wish me well. That’s what real friends do.”
Derek made girls go wild when he appeared on the stage. Noticing how he was wearing a rosary, I told him to use it also for prayer and not just as fashion accessory. Derek simply smiled and showed me a tattoo of a cross behind his left ear. He told me, “Don’t worry, I pray. Jesus has done a lot for me.”
Aiza brought his entire band, the Pogi Boys, with her on tour. They performed for an hour and a half playing sweet romantic songs, which she lovingly dedicated to her wife Liza Diño, who also joined the trip.
Note that Aiza and Liza support lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) couples who feel lost or unaccepted by society. They have just completed the indie documentary film “Traslacion: Ang Paglakad sa Altar Ng Alanganin.”
Liza shared, “The docu is a spin-off of one of the works of Direk Will Fredo. It started with the CBCP (Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines) commissioning several directors to cover Pope Francis’ arrival in the Philippines. They went on to discuss several points that the Pope will tackle. Among the topics was gender equality, at dalawa kami ni Aiza na kinuha ni Direk Will to talk about the issue, among other interviewees. It was so candid that it inspired the director to pursue another documentary and so the birth of ‘Traslacion.’”
After the concert in Abu Dhabi, I left the group for Dubai to tape an episode of “Karaokray,” which I host. Apparently, a lot of Filipinos and other nationalities watch the program, proving true the saying, “Laugh and the whole world laughs with you.”
